review.title: An enhanced neural network based approach towards object extraction
review.abstract: The improvements in spectral and spatial resolution of the satellite images have facilitated the automatic extraction and identification of the features from satellite images and aerial photographs. An automatic object extraction method is presented for extracting and identifying the various objects from satellite images and the accuracy of the system is verified with regard to IRS satellite images. The system is based on neural network and simulates the process of visual interpretation from remote sensing images and hence increases the efficiency of image analysis. This approach obtains the basic characteristics of the various features and the performance is enhanced by the automatic learning approach, intelligent interpretation, and intelligent interpolation. The major advantage of the method is its simplicity and that the system identifies the features not only based on pixel value but also based on the shape, haralick features etc of the objects. Further the system allows flexibility for identifying the features within the same category based on size and shape. The successful application of the system verified its effectiveness and the accuracy of the system were assessed by ground truth verification.

metadata.title: An enhanced neural network based approach towards object extraction

sections.text: 102 IEEE TGRSImproving the spectral and spatial resolution of satellite images has facilitated the automatic extraction and identification of features from satellite images and aerial photographs. An automatic object extraction method for extracting and identifying various objects from satellite images is presented, and the accuracy of the system is verified with respect to IRS satellite images. The system is based on neural networks and simulates the process of visual interpretation from remote sensing images, thus increasing the efficiency of image analysis. This approach maintains the basic features of the various features and performance is enhanced by the automatic learning approach, intelligent interpretation and intelligent interpretation. The great advantage of the method is its simplicity and that the system identifies the features not only on the basis of the pixel value, but also on the shape, haralick characteristics, etc. of the objects. In addition, the system allows flexibility in identifying features within the same category based on the shape and accuracy of the system based on its effectiveness and application.

sections.heading: 2. METHOD
sections.text: The satellite images, namely PAN, CARTOSAT and Google Earth images of the Bhopal range, are used as test images from which the various characteristics are extracted; the images are first adjusted for contrast by adjusting the histogram and the edges are detected by a sophisticated edge detector to detect the boundaries of various common characteristics, and in the event of erosion of bright characteristics followed by dilation is applied; the processed image is then fed into the trained neural network to extract or select the characteristics, and the selected characteristics are again subjected to a curve adjustment; the characteristics outside the required boundary are eliminated by defining the pixel as black; the textural characteristics of the Haralick are processed along with the pixel value and shape to identify the characteristics; the Haralick characteristics include energy, correlation, inertia, entropy, inverse difference, sum projection, sum section, sum variation, sum variation.

sections.heading: 2.1 Training of Neural net for feature detection and extraction
sections.text: The neural network, which is specific to each attribute, is first trained by assigning column vectors of an input matrix to the various example images. Each column of the input matrix is a attribute vector to which we want to find out what class this attribute belongs. For each of these attribute vectors, their distance to the desired attribute vectors is calculated and the weights of the hidden layers are adjusted or the network is learned. Furthermore, the SOM network is trained to be activated for detection.

sections.heading: 2.2 Feature Detection using trained neural net
sections.text: The image from which a feature is to be extracted is flattened, i.e. converted into a column vector shape and fed to the label-specific neural network, which resembles the group to the desired feature and the specified similarity. The image and string displaying the feature to be extracted Sharpen the image Detection of bright small features by erosion followed by tolerance Detection of edges and boundaries by the cunning operator Extract Haralick features, shape and pixel values. Feed the image to the trained neural network to detect the feature. Outline the extracted feature Applicable curve fit Detection of the rules stored in the prolog to clearly eliminate the features outside the prescribed boundary. Use the feature to adjust the value of hidden layer neurons (during the training phase) Detection of the specific features using SOM networks.

sections.heading: 3. Results
sections.text: The results of this research show that a considerable success has been achieved with the method. NN approaches applied are effectively better than the existing methods and accuracy is demonstrated by the extraction of roads, rivers, buildings etc. across the study areas. The efficiency of the traditional classification approaches with respect to the applied NN approaches has been evaluated using the various statistical measures and the results are summarised in the table. Earth is examined with reference to the Google Earth and Differential Global Positioning System (DGPS).

sections.heading: 3.1 Extraction of road network
sections.text: The system has been tested to extract the road networks from the PAN, Google Earth, LANDSAT image sensor image for the new market area of the city of Bhopal, and the results are as shown in Fig. 2-4. The intermediate time of extraction from the PAN image is shown in Fig. 2 (a) and the extracted network is shown in Fig. 2 (c). The entire road network of the area has been successfully extracted and breaks off due to shadows and obstacles, successfully eliminated by intelligent interpolation, as shown in the results shown below. The road network extracted from the Google Earth image is as shown 108 IEE TGR parameters, and the result of the road network extracted from the Google Earth image based on width is as shown. The accuracy of the extracted features has been verified by soil truth checking and field visits.

sections.heading: 3.2 Extraction of lake from PAN image
sections.text: The lake extracted from the Bhopal PAN sensor image is also shown below, the steps in which, as described in the algorithm, the intermediate result is shown as shown in Figure 5 (a) and the extracted water body as shown in Figure 5 (c).

sections.heading: 3.3 Extraction of water bodies from LANDSAT image
sections.text: The waters taken from the LANDSAT TM image of the Wardha River Basin are also shown in Fig. 6. The sensitivity of the context of the system and the use of Haralick characteristics help to derive rivers on their own. Results can be used to record changes in river flow over a period of years. Drained waters are shown as follows:

sections.heading: 3.4 Extraction of vehicle from Google Earth image
sections.text: The advanced feature of the system in extracting certain features is evident in the separate extraction of each vehicle from a Google Earth image, as shown in Fig.7.Here, the system has used the rules stored in the prolog database to distinguish small buildings from vehicles, and a particular vehicle has also been selected on the basis of size and shape parameters.a) Original image b) Intermediate image c) Recognized feature 109 IEEE TGRS

sections.heading: 4. CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: Intelligent interpretation of the system by means of a set of rules stored in the prologue and intelligent interpolation by means of curve matching make the system superior to existing methods; the system correctly identifies the features by using the Haralick characteristics, shape of the objects and pixel values for object extraction; the system was able to precisely extract the various features from the given satellite images (LISS III, LISS IV, PAN, etc.); and the accuracy of the system was tested by verifying soil truthfulness; the results showed that the system performs the existing methods in terms of accuracy and number of extractable features; the system implemented in the laboratory software Mat is computationally simple and faster than its counterparts based on backpropagation implemented in c and other languages; future improvements to the system include improving the system by using context information and general rules for image analysis.

referenceMentions.context: There are a number of object extraction algorithms and most of them are specific to features to be extracted and adopts computationally complex methods for the extraction (Shuichi, 2011).

Efficiencies of various methodologies in this context are affected by different factors such as scene complexity, feature variability, undefined feature geometry, and sensor resolution (Bruno, 1998; Lari, 2011). There are a number of object extraction algorithms and most of them are specific to features to be extracted and adopts computationally complex methods for the extraction (Shuichi, 2011). Neural Network (NN) technique that models the human brain has the ability to derive meaning from complicated or imprecise data. This ability of NN is exploited to extract patterns and detect trends that are too complex to be noticed by either humans or other computer techniques. Bruno et al. (Bruno, 1998) suggested a road extraction system in which tests segments (matched filters for short road segments) was adopted to detect the road position. The method was not completely automatic since starting point and direction was to be provided. Barzohar et al (1996) discussed a road extraction system which linkers, correlation trackers, and region based followers for detection.

Road tracing based on profile matching and kalman filtering was introduced by Vosselman et al (1995) how ever seemed to be noise sensitive especially in case of small distances between the profiles.

Efficiencies of various methodologies in this context are affected by different factors such as scene complexity, feature variability, undefined feature geometry, and sensor resolution (Bruno, 1998; Lari, 2011). There are a number of object extraction algorithms and most of them are specific to features to be extracted and adopts computationally complex methods for the extraction (Shuichi, 2011). Neural Network (NN) technique that models the human brain has the ability to derive meaning from complicated or imprecise data. This ability of NN is exploited to extract patterns and detect trends that are too complex to be noticed by either humans or other computer techniques. Bruno et al. (Bruno, 1998) suggested a road extraction system in which tests segments (matched filters for short road segments) was adopted to detect the road position. The method was not completely automatic since starting point and direction was to be provided. Barzohar et al (1996) discussed a road extraction system which linkers, correlation trackers, and region based followers for detection. Road tracing based on profile matching and kalman filtering was introduced by Vosselman et al (1995) how ever seemed to be noise sensitive especially in case of small distances between the profiles. Model based road extraction from images proposed by Carsten (1998) also failed due to the lack of topology consideration as well as context.

A semiautomatic feature extraction based on snakes was suggested by John et al (1986) however the method needs manual involvement and the snakes seems to get distorted in the proximity of other features in the image.

A semiautomatic feature extraction based on snakes was suggested by John et al (1986) however the method needs manual involvement and the snakes seems to get distorted in the proximity of other features in the image. Gruen (1997) suggested a road extraction method based on wavelet transformed image and least square matching but seemed to be less

103 IEEE TGRS efficient for the non linear features. A map-based semantic modelling for the extraction of objects was proposed by Quint et al (1995) but the efficiency was limited by the mere use of line segments for image analysis and accuracy was dependent on the availability of the map at hand.

103 IEEE TGRS efficient for the non linear features. A map-based semantic modelling for the extraction of objects was proposed by Quint et al (1995) but the efficiency was limited by the mere use of line segments for image analysis and accuracy was dependent on the availability of the map at hand. Wang et al (2009) proposed a fuzzy mask based method in order to perform road pixels extraction in which a road membership value is attributed to each pixel.
Lau Bee Theng et al (2008), in his methods adopted active contour model to extract objects like land parcels and buildings from high resolution satellite imageries.

Lau Bee Theng et al (2008), in his methods adopted active contour model to extract objects like land parcels and buildings from high resolution satellite imageries. A technique that integrates the advantages of both fuzzy theory and Hopfield type neural network for object extraction from noisy background was proposed by Bhattacharyya et al (1998). Many approaches based on neural networks for road detection did not achieve significant improvements as they relied on a small context (9×9 pixels being the largest) for prediction and used very little training data (Boggess, 1993).

Lau Bee Theng et al (2008), in his methods adopted active contour model to extract objects like land parcels and buildings from high resolution satellite imageries. A technique that integrates the advantages of both fuzzy theory and Hopfield type neural network for object extraction from noisy background was proposed by Bhattacharyya et al (1998). Many approaches based on neural networks for road detection did not achieve significant improvements as they relied on a small context (9×9 pixels being the largest) for prediction and used very little training data (Boggess, 1993). An automatic road extraction system using a neural network with millions of trainable weights was suggested by Mnih et al (2010) how ever considered only pixel values as parameter for the extraction.

Lau Bee Theng et al (2008), in his methods adopted active contour model to extract objects like land parcels and buildings from high resolution satellite imageries. A technique that integrates the advantages of both fuzzy theory and Hopfield type neural network for object extraction from noisy background was proposed by Bhattacharyya et al (1998). Many approaches based on neural networks for road detection did not achieve significant improvements as they relied on a small context (9×9 pixels being the largest) for prediction and used very little training data (Boggess, 1993). An automatic road extraction system using a neural network with millions of trainable weights was suggested by Mnih et al (2010) how ever considered only pixel values as parameter for the extraction. Most of the errors in the current systems are due to the ambiguous nature of the labelling task. Porway et al. (2008) used a grammar to model relationships between objects such as cars, trees, and roofs for the purpose of parsing aerial images.

An object extraction method was proposed Jiangye Yuan et al(2009) based on locally excitatory globally inhibitory oscillator networks (LEGION) in which oscillation network can segment the image and extract objects by the scene and object feature.

An object extraction method was proposed Jiangye Yuan et al(2009) based on locally excitatory globally inhibitory oscillator networks (LEGION) in which oscillation network can segment the image and extract objects by the scene and object feature. A knowledge-based method for automatic road extraction from high resolution remotely sensed images was proposed by Trinder et al (2003). They described road structures as a generalized anti parallel pair and their radiometric and geometric properties are expressed as rules in Prolog by virtue of which the extraction was accomplished.

metadata.abstractText: ABSTRACT The improvements in spectral and spatial resolution of the satellite images have facilitated the automatic extraction and identification of the features from satellite images and aerial photographs. An automatic object extraction method is presented for extracting and identifying the various objects from satellite images and the accuracy of the system is verified with regard to IRS satellite images. The system is based on neural network and simulates the process of visual interpretation from remote sensing images and hence increases the efficiency of image analysis. This approach obtains the basic characteristics of the various features and the performance is enhanced by the automatic learning approach, intelligent interpretation, and intelligent interpolation. The major advantage of the method is its simplicity and that the system identifies the features not only based on pixel value but also based on the shape, haralick features etc of the objects. Further the system allows flexibility for identifying the features within the same category based on size and shape. The successful application of the system verified its effectiveness and the accuracy of the system were assessed by ground truth verification.
